title: How to Safely Transport a Kayak on a Hyundai Ioniq 5
description: A step-by-step guide to installing a roof rack, mounting a kayak carrier, and securely fastening your kayak to the roof of your Hyundai Ioniq 5 for safe travel.
tools_required: Roof rack system compatible with the Ioniq 5 (crossbars and towers)
Two bow and stern tie-down lines

steps.title: Install the Roof Rack Crossbars
steps.description: Begin by installing the roof rack system. The Ioniq 5 has fixed mounting points hidden under small plastic covers in the roof's side channels. Carefully pry these covers open. Attach the rack towers to these points according to your rack manufacturer's instructions, ensuring they are level and parallel. A typical spread between the bars is 24-30 inches. Tighten all bolts to the specified torque using the provided tool.
warnings: Do not overtighten bolts, as this can damage the vehicle's mounting points.
Ensure the crossbars are rated to carry the combined weight of your kayak and carrier.
steps.image_prompt: Photorealistic, eye-level shot of a person's hands carefully tightening the final bolt on a black roof rack tower onto the fixed mounting point of a lucid blue Hyundai Ioniq 5. The car is parked in a clean suburban driveway on a bright, overcast day. The focus is sharp on the tower and the tool, with the rest of the car slightly blurred in the background.

steps.title: Mount the Kayak Carrier
steps.description: Decide where you want to position the kayak (driver's side, passenger's side, or center). Attach your kayak carrier, such as J-cradles, to the crossbars. Slide them into position and secure them loosely. Briefly place the kayak on the carrier to check for proper spacing, ensuring it rests securely in the cradles. Remove the kayak and then fully tighten the carrier's hardware.
tips: Positioning the carrier on the driver's or passenger's side can make it easier to load and unload from the side of the car using a step stool.
steps.image_prompt: Photorealistic close-up shot of a person attaching a black J-cradle kayak carrier to an aerodynamic roof rack crossbar on a lucid blue Hyundai Ioniq 5. The person's hands are shown tightening the clamp mechanism underneath the bar. The setting is a suburban driveway with soft, even lighting from an overcast sky.

steps.title: Prepare Straps and Protect the Vehicle
steps.description: Before lifting the kayak, prepare your straps. Unbuckle two cam buckle straps and drape them over the kayak carrier, one for the front and one for the rear, with the buckles hanging on the side you'll be standing on for easy access. If you're concerned about scratching the car, place a blanket or large towel over the rear of the roof and spoiler.
tips: Having the straps ready will prevent you from having to hold the kayak in place while fumbling for them.
steps.image_prompt: Photorealistic wide shot of the side of the lucid blue Hyundai Ioniq 5, showing the installed roof rack and J-cradles. Two yellow cam buckle straps are draped over the cradles, ready for loading. A folded blanket is placed over the rear spoiler and back window. The car is in a suburban driveway under an overcast sky.

steps.title: Lift and Position the Kayak
steps.description: With a partner, stand on opposite ends of the kayak. Using your legs, lift the kayak overhead. Walk towards the car and carefully rest the edge of the kayak on the rear J-cradle or the protective blanket. Slide the kayak forward until it is centered and sitting securely in both J-cradles. If loading alone, lift one end onto the rear of the car first, then lift the other end and slide it forward.
warnings: Always lift with your legs, not your back, to prevent injury.
Lifting with a partner is strongly recommended to avoid injury and damage to the vehicle.
steps.image_prompt: Photorealistic action shot of two people carefully lifting a bright orange 10-foot kayak onto the J-cradles of a lucid blue Hyundai Ioniq 5. The kayak is halfway on, with one person at the bow and one at the stern guiding it into place. The scene is set in a suburban driveway with soft, diffused light.

steps.title: Secure the Kayak with Hull Straps
steps.description: Take the strap draped over the front carrier. Toss the non-buckle end under the crossbar and back up on the other side of the kayak. Feed the strap through the cam buckle. Pull the strap taut until the kayak is snug in its carrier. Do not overtighten, as this can deform a plastic kayak. The buckle should be easily accessible and not against the car's paint. Repeat for the rear strap. Secure the excess strap length by tying it off.
tips: Twist the straps a few times where they span open air to prevent annoying wind humming while driving.
warnings: Never use ratchet straps on the hull of a kayak; their force can easily crack or warp the boat. Use only cam buckle straps.
steps.image_prompt: Photorealistic, detailed close-up shot focusing on a person's hands threading a yellow cam buckle strap and pulling it taut. The strap is wrapped over the hull of an orange kayak and under the roof rack crossbar of the Ioniq 5. The cam buckle mechanism is clearly visible. The background is the side of the car in the driveway setting.

steps.title: Attach Bow and Stern Tie-Downs
steps.description: Secure the bow and stern of the kayak to the front and rear of the vehicle. Use hood anchor straps for the front; open the hood, place the loop straps inside on either side of the engine bay, and close the hood on them. Attach the bow line from the kayak's bow handle to these two points, forming a 'V'. For the stern, find a secure metal anchor point underneath the rear bumper or use a trunk anchor strap. The lines should be snug, but not overly tight.
warnings: Do not attach tie-downs to plastic bumper components or the spoiler.
These lines are critical for preventing the kayak from lifting or shifting in crosswinds or during sudden stops.
steps.image_prompt: Photorealistic shot showing the front of the lucid blue Hyundai Ioniq 5. The hood is slightly ajar, revealing a black nylon hood anchor strap on one side. A red tie-down line runs from the bow handle of the orange kayak down to the loop of the anchor strap. The focus is on the connection point of the tie-down hook to the anchor strap.

steps.title: Perform a Final Safety Check
steps.description: Before driving, perform a thorough check. Grab the kayak and firmly shake it side-to-side and front-to-back. The kayak should move as one with the car, with no significant wiggle or play. Double-check that all buckles are secure and all excess strap material is tied down so it doesn't flap against the car. Plan to re-check all straps after the first 15-20 minutes of driving.
tips: It's a good habit to check your straps every time you stop for gas or a break on longer trips.
steps.image_prompt: Photorealistic shot from a low angle, looking up at the fully secured orange kayak on the lucid blue Hyundai Ioniq 5. A person is shown grabbing the side of the kayak and giving it a firm shake to test its stability. The car is ready to go in the suburban driveway, with the sky clear and bright.

safety_notes: Be aware of your vehicle's new height. Avoid low-clearance areas like parking garages and drive-thrus.
The kayak will act like a sail in crosswinds. Be prepared for the car to handle differently, especially on highways and bridges.
Check your local regulations regarding vehicle load overhang and the use of flags on the end of your load.
Regularly inspect your roof rack and straps for wear and tear, and replace them if they show signs of damage.
